Legal_Issue: Whether the Officer breached procedural fairness or erred in assessing Ms. Parveen's likelihood of economic establishment
Procedural_Stage: Initial assessment, pre-refusal letter, applicant's response, final review, judicial review
Evidence_Assessment: Ms. Parveen met minimum language requirements but lacked sufficient proficiency for her intended occupation; Officer considered submitted evidence
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate likelihood of economic establishment
Legal_Rule: Officer's decisions on economic establishment are reviewed for reasonableness; procedural fairness requires notice and opportunity to respond but not obligation to seek clarification
Procedural_Issue: Allegation of breach of procedural fairness
Grounds_for_Claim: Insufficient language skills affecting economic establishment
Decision_Maker: Immigration Officer (two officers conducted final review)
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: No breach; applicant received pre-refusal letter and responded
Key_Evidence_Considered: Language proficiency test results, application materials, response to pre-refusal letter
Legal_Framework: Canadian immigration law, procedural fairness principles
Applicant_Challenge: Refusal of immigration application due to insufficient language skills
Legal_Rule_Source: Administrative law, Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Defendant_Response: Officer assessed evidence and concluded lack of economic establishment likelihood
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, language test scores, application forms
Legal_Provision: IRPA sections related to economic class applications and procedural fairness
Legal_Provision_Cited: IRPA provisions on economic establishment and procedural fairness
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Unlikely to become economically established due to language proficiency
Applicable_Process: Pre-refusal process with right to respond, followed by judicial review
Governing_Rule: Duty of procedural fairness; standard of reasonableness in administrative review
